title: Kublai Khan Hunting （畫元世祖出獵圖）
creator: Liu Guandao 劉貫道（1258-1336）
description: Hanging scroll, Ink and colors on silk, 182.9 x 104.1 cm |  This painting by Liu Guandao depicts a scene of the emperor Kublai Khan hunting along with his empress and several attendants in the Gobi desert. The figure in white near the center dressed in white is thought to be Kublai, while the figure next to him also in white is the empress. Several of the attendants are of obvious non-Han Chinese ethnicity, showing a diverse group of people. There are also a variety of different animals such as the riding horses, a dog, birds, a cheetah and camels.
subject: Kublai Khan;Animals;Desert;Figure; Horses; Hanging scroll
rights: Copyright © National Palace Museum. All Rights Reserved

title: Zhong Kui (Zhongshan) Traveling (中山出遊圖）
creator: Gong Kai 龔開（1222-1307）
description: Handscroll, Ink on paper, 32.8 x 169.5 cm | This painting by Gong Kai depicts a scene of the legendary Demon Queller, Zhong Kui, on an excursion with his sister. The legend of Zhong Kui came from the Tang dynasty Emperor Xuanzong, who one day dreamt of a large man (Zhong Kui) appearing to attack and devour a demon that broke into Xuanzong’s palace when he fell ill with a fever. Since then, the figure of Zhong Kui served as a talisman against demons and harmful spirits. Scholars have argued that this painting by Gong Kai contains possible messages, perhaps in political protest against the Mongol rule or as a self-reflective critique of fellow scholar-officials.
subject: Supernatural;Zhong Kui;Procession;Myth;Handscroll
source: Freer Gallery of Art, Smithsonian Institution
